column3: Why diabetes mellitus is risk factor tuberculosis?
column4: Immune function: Diabetes, especially uncontrolled diabetes, causes neutrophils to not behave as well as they should, so infections are both more likely and more frequent. Tuberculosis is one of these, and tends to be more severe in a poorly controlled diabetic.
column5: There are a few ways that diabetes mellitus can increase the risk of tuberculosis:  1) People with diabetes mellitus are more likely to have underlying conditions that make them more susceptible to tuberculosis, such as HIV/AIDS, malnutrition, or liver disease.  2) Diabetes mellitus can weaken the immune system, making it more difficult for the body to fight off infection.  3) People with diabetes mellitus are more likely to have diabetes-related complications such as nerve damage, which can make it difficult to cough and clear the lungs of bacteria.  4) People with diabetes mellitus are more likely to develop pulmonary complications from tuberculosis, such as cavities in the lungs.

column3: I have read that if you have 3 normal paps smears in a row, you can go every 5 years for a paps.. is this true? If so, would that catch cancer or would too much time have passed? Don’t uterine and cervical cancer spread quickly?
column4: If you are low risk, not immunocompromised, and you your last 3 paps have been normal, then it is ok to defer pap testing to every 5 years as long as you are also testing for HPV with the pap smear. Pap smears detect cervical cancer (predominantly caused by HPV), and it is very slow growing. Uterine cancer is a separate problem, not detected by pap smears. Report any abnormal bleeding to your GYN
column5: The pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer, but not for uterine cancer. The American Cancer Society recommends yearly pap smears for all women who are or have been sexually active, and who have a cervix. Once a woman has had 3 normal pap smears in a row, she may have the test every 2-3 years. However, if at any time she has an abnormal pap smear, she should have another pap smear within one year.

column3: I have had bone pain for 9 months. I have been tested for cancer, brain diseases, nerve conditions and any rheumatologic possibilities. Suggestions?

If that is normal- you should consider pet scan ( superior than skeletal bone survey) or MRI of spines to detect bony lesion that may be associated with your plasma cell disorder.
column5: The most likely explanation is that the pain is due to inflammation of the joints (arthritis). The two most common types of arthritis are osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. Osteoarthritis is due to wear and tear of the joints and is more common in older patients. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks the joints. Both of these types of arthritis can be treated with anti-inflammatory medications, physical therapy, and weight loss if necessary. If the pain is severe, you may also need to take pain medications. If you have not already done so, you should see a rheumatologist (a doctor who specializes in arthritis) for further evaluation and treatment.

column3: I'm very concerned and need a second opinion on my daughter's scapula x-ray. She has a bone poking out from her back that is bothersome.

Growth plate injuries are common in children and adolescents, and usually occur during growth spurts. Treatment typically involves rest, ice, and elevation. If the pain is severe, your daughter may need to see an orthopedic surgeon for further evaluation.

column3: Is the accuracy of test at 7 weeks using the 4th Ag/Ab? 2 week test rapid test = negativ,3 week test rapid test = negative, 4 week test 4th AG/AB = Non reactive, 7 week test 4th Ag/AB =Non reactive.i have Diarrhea and Weight Loss. Does the accuracy?

column3: Is tamoxifen safe and can I take it? I am a 67-year-old white female living alone. Last year i had early catch stage-1 breast cancer. I next had a lumpectomy and only one treatment of chemotherapy. I was scheduled for four treatments. The side affects
column4: If your breast cancer was estrogen receptor-negative then you will not benefit from hormonal adjuvant therapy like tamoxifen (actually women who are past their menopause should be on Arimidex (anastrozole) not tamoxifen) either way you will not benefit from those since your mass is estrogen receptor negative. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while you are taking this medication.

column3: What tips do you have for a patient recovering from a stroke?

column5: The tips for a patient recovering from a stroke are the following:   1. Encourage the patient to move as soon as possible after the stroke. Help the patient to eat healthy and drink plenty of fluids. A healthy diet will help the patient to regain strength and energy.  3. Encourage the patient to stay active and to participate in rehabilitation exercises. Exercise will help the patient to regain movement and strength.  4. Help the patient to manage his or her stress and anxiety. Stress can worsen the symptoms of a stroke, so it is important to help the patient to relax and to stay positive.
